reasoning:
Well, I’d rather say “no” than try to force myself into a deal I don’t fully understand—and Microsoft lies largely outside my circle of competence. Here’s why I’m steering clear:

1. Circle of Competence: I’m comfortable with consumer staples, insurance, banks, railroads and simple industrials. Microsoft’s enterprise software and cloud-computing business isn’t something I can easily value or predict 20 years out. “Risk comes from not knowing what you’re doing,” and I don’t know this space nearly as well as I know See’s Candies or Coca-Cola.

2. Competitive Moat: The operating margin at 88.6% is eye-popping, but the rest of the moat analysis is weak—only 0 of 10 years above 15% ROE and inconsistent earnings growth. High performance stability suggests some stickiness, but I’ve seen too many tech firms blow their advantages when the next big thing arrives.

3. Management Quality: There’s been a recent stock issuance, which could dilute existing shareholders, and no meaningful dividend. Warren Gates says, “I like managers who act like owners.” I’m not convinced these managers are signaling ownership spirit to shareholders in the same way they did at GEICO or BNSF.

4. Financial Health & Consistency: The debt-to-equity ratio is conservative, but ROE at 3.7% and ROIC at 2.9% are far below the 15%+ I look for in great businesses. Worse, total earnings have declined 18.4% over the last 10 periods—hardly the kind of consistent growth I crave.

5. Valuation vs. Intrinsic Value: The three-stage DCF pegs a conservative intrinsic value around $16,024, yet the market has priced in far more—resulting in a negative 94% margin of safety. I don’t buy businesses that cost more than they’re worth. I’d rather wait for prices to come around.

6. Long-Term Prospects & Red Flags: The world’s reliance on cloud and software may continue, but shifting technology landscapes can erode moats overnight. I’d expect more stable earnings from a well-branded consumer staple or utility.

7. Comparison to My Portfolio Opportunities: I’d take a fair price on Coca-Cola, Apple in my book, or BNSF any day. They bring durable moats, honest capital allocation and clear growth paths. This Microsoft opportunity doesn’t check the same boxes, and its lofty price only heightens the risk.

In short, I’d pass on Microsoft today. There’s no shame in saying no to an overvalued or unfamiliar business. My favorite holding period may be forever—but only after I’ve found something I truly understand and can buy at the right price.
